entry.title: ‚ÄúGov. Jared Polis on Wednesday issued an executive order...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúGov. Jared Polis on Wednesday issued an executive order banning Colorado landlords from evicting tenants who can prove financial hardship because of the coronavirus crisis.

The order, which lasts at least 30 days, comes after the Democrat faced months of pressure from housing advocates to protect renters from losing their homes during the pandemic.‚Äù

The Colorado Sun

The order, which lasts at least 30 days, comes after the Democrat faced months of pressure from housing advocates

coloradosun.com

Colorado governor bans evictions for tenants who can prove financial hardship because of coronavirus

The order, which lasts at least 30 days, comes after the Democrat faced months of pressure from housing advocatesThe order, which lasts at least 30 days, comes after the Democrat faced months of pressure from housing advocates

entry.title: "In what appears to be a first in Colorado, elected leaders...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

"In what appears to be a first in Colorado, elected leaders in Aurora on Monday banned no-knock raids by police ‚Äî the latest effort by city leaders to grapple with law enforcement tactics that have come under scrutiny nationwide.

The City Council voted 7-3 to prohibit police from forcibly entering a property without first identifying themselves as officers of the law. The measure was brought forward by Councilwoman Angela Lawson following the death of Breonna Taylor, who was shot in March by police as she slept in her own home."

The Denver Post

In what appears to be a first in Colorado, elected leaders in Aurora on Monday banned no-knock raids by police ‚Äî the latest effort by city leaders to grapple with controversial law enforcemen‚Ä¶

denverpost.com

Aurora becomes first Colorado city to ban ‚Äúno-knock‚Äù warrants

entry.title: ‚ÄúColorado began in-person early voting statewide Monday, and...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúColorado began in-person early voting statewide Monday, and voters will find much changed to adapt to public health concerns surrounding the coronavirus.

Across the state, counties have set up voting procedures meticulously designed to address health guidelines and voter fears about COVID-19, using money from the federal CARES Act to buy everything from gloves to cheap pens.‚Äù

The Colorado Sun

Colorado counties have set up voting procedures to address health guidelines and voter fears about COVID-19, using money from the federal CARES Act to buy everything from gloves to disposable pens.

coloradosun.com

Colorado opens statewide in-person voting with rules designed to prevent coronavirus outbreaks

entry.title: ‚ÄúThe Regional Transportation District board of directors will...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúThe Regional Transportation District board of directors will vote Tuesday evening on whether to offer free rides on Nov. 3, Election Day.

"The folks that are utilizing our services are Black, brown, Indigenous folks who are dependent on public transportation," she said. "And we want to really encourage their participation in voting, in our democracy."

Denverite

Shontel Lewis, the RTD board member who authored the resolution, said free rides would be "a public good."

cpr.org

RTD Board To Vote On Free Election Day Rides

Shontel Lewis, the RTD board member who authored the resolution, said free rides would be "a public good."Shontel Lewis, the RTD board member who authored the resolution, said free rides would be "a public good."Visit the Voting Information Center for official election resources and local updates. entry.title: "Starting Monday, polling places (or Voter Service and...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

"Starting Monday, polling places (or Voter Service and Polling Centers, in the vernacular of elections officials) will open across the state to give voters the chance to record in person their preferences on national, state and local races and issues.

Monday is also the day Colorado‚Äôs 383 election drop boxes must start accepting ballots from voters."

The Denver Post

It‚Äôs a tradition fast fading in Colorado elections but the act of venturing out to the polls and squeezing into a booth to cast a vote is still a cherished ‚Äî and for some voters ‚Äî‚Ä¶

denverpost.com

In-person voting begins Monday for Colorado residents

entry.title: ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre working off of a list of students that teachers...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre working off of a list of students that teachers have flagged: students who haven‚Äôt shown up online at all or aren‚Äôt engaging with classes from home. Attendance averaged 77 percent in September. In the first week of October it was 81 percent and it's steadily been creeping up. Districtwide attendance is 88 percent.‚Äù

Colorado Public Radio

Lake Middle School had just built up a school culture where kids felt respected, proud and accepted. But that all came to a screeching halt when the pandemic hit.

cpr.org

entry.title: ‚ÄúThe CalWood fire started Saturday and quickly grew to the...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúThe CalWood fire started Saturday and quickly grew to the largest wildfire in Boulder County‚Äôs history, burning between Jamestown and Lyons. Nearly 3,000 residents were evacuated Saturday afternoon as the smoke plume billowed over the Front Range.‚Äù

The Denver Post

The CalWood fire in Boulder County has grown to at least 8,788 acres, or about 13 square miles, according to a map published Sunday by the Boulder County Emergency Operations Center.

denverpost.com

CalWood fire update: Number of homes lost is ‚Äúlikely large‚Äù as blaze tops 8,700 acres

entry.title: ‚ÄúDenver Mayor Michael Hancock announced new limits on group...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúDenver Mayor Michael Hancock announced new limits on group gatherings and new requirements for face coverings in more settings. Officials warned that more restrictions on restaurants, bars and other businesses will be implemented if the number of COVID-19 cases continues to increase.‚Äù

Cbs4 denver

Group gatherings are now limited to five people, instead of 10, and face coverings are now required in more outdoor settings.

denver.cbslocal.com|By CBS Denver

New COVID-19 Restrictions: Denver Limits Group Gatherings To 5 People, Requires Face Masks In More Settings

entry.title: More than 300,000 Coloradans have cast their ballot - this is a...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

More than 300,000 Coloradans have cast their ballot - this is a 2,377 percent increase compared to this time in the 2016 election. Still trying to figure out your ballot? Check out my Ballot Guide for my thoughts on the measures, info on voting, & more.

Visit the Voting Information Center for official election resources and local updates. Get Voting Information

entry.title: ‚ÄúAs of Thursday, 436,433 voters had returned their ballots,...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúAs of Thursday, 436,433 voters had returned their ballots, according to the Colorado Secretary of State, with Democrats and Unaffiliated voters outpacing Republicans in these early returns.‚Äù

Colorado Public Radio

‚ÄúWith everything going on with the Post Office and national politics, I decided I didn‚Äôt want to take any chances.‚Äù

entry.title: ‚ÄúThe mask-wearing order expands on Denver‚Äôs order requiring...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúThe mask-wearing order expands on Denver‚Äôs order requiring face coverings in all indoor settings. Organized athletic programming ‚Äî like college and high school sports, as well as organized youth and adult leagues ‚Äî is exempt from the expanded order. People who are by themselves are also exempt.

The order is in effect immediately and indefinitely.‚Äù

The Colorado Sun

New public health orders limiting people's movement were also unveiled Friday in Adams and Arapahoe counties

entry.title: ‚ÄúHancock said the city is ‚Äúbrimming on the edge of a...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúHancock said the city is ‚Äúbrimming on the edge of a crisis‚Äù that could endanger health and damage the economy.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre taking these additional steps today to reduce the spread of this virus in our community because right now, we need to do more,‚Äù Hancock said, adding the ‚Äúhard work‚Äù to curb the virus should be done now so people can enjoy the looming holiday season with family.‚Äù

Denverite

COVID-19 infections rates and hospitalizations are on the rise.

entry.title: ‚ÄúState Rep. Leslie Herod, who represents Denver, said even...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúState Rep. Leslie Herod, who represents Denver, said even though voting is relatively easy in Colorado compared to other states, suppression still exists.

‚ÄúWhile we may not have any confirmed cases on the record yet, or video, I would say be aware, be vigilant,‚Äù Herod said. ‚ÄúIf you see something, take a picture and report it ‚Ä¶ This is a different year, this is a different election cycle ‚Ä¶ The most important thing is your voice is heard and your vote is cast.‚Äù

Colorado Public Radio

Authorities have been looking into stories circulating on NextDoor and Facebook about intimidating people hanging around ballot drop boxes, but so far none panned out.

cpr.org

Social Media Foments Stories of Voter Intimidation But Local Officials Say So Far They Aren‚Äôt True

entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúColorado voters are already turning out for the Nov. 3 election, with more than 300,000 ballots cast in the first days of early voting this week, officials announced Thursday.

Secretary of State Jena Griswold said 300,795 Coloradans had voted by Wednesday.‚Äù

entry.title: "The coronavirus pandemic has been stressful for all...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

"The coronavirus pandemic has been stressful for all Coloradans. And undocumented immigrants in Colorado are facing some unique stressors themselves as they deal with the pandemic ‚Äî severely limited access to health care, looming deportation concerns for them or their families, and the particular difficulty of getting mental health help."

Colorado Public Radio

It‚Äôs a sunny Saturday morning in a Pueblo neighborhood, and the scent of steak and eggs drifts through the air in Ana Agustin‚Äôs home. She‚Äôs making breakfast for her cousins. The women are keeping up their weekly tradition of hanging out on weekends and basking in each other‚Äôs friendship.

cpr.org

entry.title: Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have community support for this work. We all have a story to tell. Our stories are our strength and our voices will be heard.

"Forget political stereotypes: This history-making legislator is unapologetically progressive, is insistent that state government can be bipartisan (even now), and wants to transform the criminal justice system. And that's just the start of her ambitions.‚Äù
